Title: If integral is zero and function is continuous and non negative, then what about the function?
Content: If $f$ is continuous on $[a,b]$, $f(x)≥0$ on $[a,b]$ and $$\int_{a}^{b} f(x) =0$$ then prove that $f(x)=0$ for all $x \in [a,b]$. I tried with Riemann's definite integral definition but couldn't proceed
AcceptedAnswer: Hint : Suppose that $f$ were not identically zero, and choose $x_0 \in (a, b)$ for which $f(x_0) > 0$. Then there exists an $\epsilon > 0$ such that $$|x - x_0| < \epsilon \implies f(x) > \frac{1}{2} f(x_0)$$ Try considering a partition of the interval containing the interval $[x_0 - \epsilon, x_0 + \epsilon]$, and compute a lower sum.
